derivation.yuyuan_name: late 15th cent. (denoting the haunch of a pig): from Old Northern French gambon, from gambe 'leg'
mid 18th cent.: apparently from Old English gamen or gamenian (see game), with survival of the -n ending
early 18th cent.: origin uncertain; the term was first used as criminals' slang in give gammon to 'give cover to a pickpocket' and keep in gammon 'distract (a victim) for a pickpocket'

entry.tran: 腌猪后腿；熏猪腿；熏猪肋肉
entry.def: Gammon is smoked or salted meat, similar to bacon, from the back leg or the side of a pig.

means.word_mean: 1. meat cut from the thigh of a hog (usually smoked)
2. hind portion of a side of bacon
